importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the third week of the government shutdown, highlighting the prolonged impact on federal workers and the public response to food insecurity during the crisis.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has now entered its third week, which underscores the growing desperation among federal employees and the mounting pressure on lawmakers to resolve the pay dispute.

keyTakeAways: Federal workers, including contractors and employees from agencies such as the Department of Commerce and the Department of Agriculture, are being furloughed or are working without pay during the shutdown.
Over 1.4 million federal employees are affected, creating widespread financial hardship and leading to increased demand for food assistance.
A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, served more than 370 households — double the expected number — showing the scale of the crisis.
Federal contractors like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams express shock at the loss of job security and financial stability amid the shutdown.
The event was organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, which required federal workers to show ID to receive aid.
GOP Senator Ron Johnson introduced a bill to pay only those federal workers still working during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for universal payment to all federal employees.
The event reflects a broader societal concern: the vulnerability of public sector workers in times of government dysfunction and economic instability.

namedEntities.name: Summer Kerksick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal contractor and market research analyst with the Rural Export Center, US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a representative example of a federal worker experiencing financial hardship due to the shutdown, highlighting personal stakes in the crisis.

namedEntities.name: Ron Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He introduced a bill that would only pay federal workers who are actively working during the shutdown, reflecting a partisan divide in policy solutions.

namedEntities.name: Pamelia Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries and a federal worker at the Department of Agriculture with 38 years of experience
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Her long-standing experience in the federal government gives her unique insight into past shutdowns, and her observation underscores the severity of current conditions.

namedEntities.name: Oliver Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Pastor at No Limits Outreach Ministries and organizer of the food bank event
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is directly involved in organizing the food assistance event, which illustrates the community and religious response to the federal shutdown crisis.

namedEntities.name: Rolanda Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Employee at the Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She exemplifies how even long-term federal employees are now facing food insecurity, challenging the perception of government jobs as financially secure.

namedEntities.name: Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Food bank in Washington, D.C. area
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It organized a large-scale food distribution event for federal workers, revealing the growing demand for emergency food aid during the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Local religious group partnering with Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It collaborated to host a food bank event, showing the role of faith-based organizations in responding to public emergencies.

namedEntities.name: US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Home to the Rural Export Center where Summer Kerksick works, illustrating how federal contractors are affected by the shutdown.

namedEntities.name: Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Where Pamelia Carter has worked for 38 years, demonstrating long-term institutional exposure to government shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Where Rolanda Williams works, showing that federal workers across agencies face similar economic consequences.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the government shutdown enters its third week, over 1.4 million federal workers—including contractors and long-term employees from agencies such as the Department of Commerce and Department of Agriculture—are furloughed or working without pay. This has led to widespread financial hardship, prompting a large-scale food bank event in Landover, Maryland, organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries. The event, which required federal employees to show work IDs, served more than 370 households—more than double the expected number—highlighting the severity of the crisis. Federal workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams express shock at losing job security and financial stability. While GOP Senator Ron Johnson proposes a limited pay plan for workers still working, Democrats push for universal compensation. The situation reflects broader societal concerns about the resilience of public sector workers in times of political gridlock and economic instability.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
